Field.ElementLabel: Social Determinants of Health

Thank you (again) for being a part of the All of Us Research Program. Many things can make us sick or keep us healthy. Where you were born or where you live, go to school, or work can affect your health. These are sometimes referred to as social factors, or the "social determinants", of health. Help us learn more by completing this survey about your neighborhood, social life, stress, and feelings about your everyday life. This survey will take less than 10 minutes to complete.

Please answer each question as honestly as possible. It is important that you answer as many questions as you can. We are looking for your own answers, and not what you think your doctors, family, or friends want you to say.

Don't feel like you have to spend a long time on each question. The first answer that comes to you is usually the best one. If you aren't sure how to answer a question, choose the best answer from the options given. Some of the questions may be sensitive. You can choose not to answer.

Field.ElementPreceedingHeader:
The neighborhood where you live may play a role in a variety of health outcomes. Sharing details about your neighborhood may help researchers better understand the relationship between a person's neighborhood and their overall well-being.
The following statements describe what your neighborhood might be like. Tell us how much you agree or disagree.
Field.ElementLabel: People around here are willing to help their neighbors.

ElementEnum.RawValue:
SDOH_1, Strongly agree 
 SDOH_2, Agree 
 SDOH_3, Neutral (neither agree nor disagree) 
 SDOH_4, Disagree 
 SDOH_5, Strongly disagree

Field.ElementLabel: People in my neighborhood generally get along with each other.

ElementEnum.RawValue:
SDOH_1, Strongly agree 
 SDOH_2, Agree 
 SDOH_3, Neutral (neither agree nor disagree) 
 SDOH_4, Disagree 
 SDOH_5, Strongly disagree

Field.ElementLabel: People in my neighborhood can be trusted.

ElementEnum.RawValue:

 SDOH_2, Agree

 SDOH_4, Disagree 
 SDOH_5, Strongly disagree

Field.ElementPreceedingHeader:
Supportive relationships may play a key role in helping people live healthy lives. Answering the following questions may help researchers learn more about the potential health benefits of supportive relationships.
People sometimes look to others for friendship, help, or other types of support. Choose the answer that best describes how often you can find support if you need it?
Field.ElementLabel: Someone to help you if you were confined to bed

ElementEnum.RawValue:
SDOH_15, None of the time 
 SDOH_16, A little of the time 
 SDOH_17, Some of the time 
 SDOH_18, Most of the time 
 SDOH_19, All of the time

 SDOH_18, Most of the time 
 SDOH_19, All of the time

Field.ElementPreceedingHeader:
People who experience discrimination may be at higher risk of negative health outcomes. Sharing your experiences with discrimination in everyday life and in healthcare settings may help researchers learn how to reduce negative health outcomes associated with discrimination.
The next statements describe how others may treat you. In your day-to-day life, how often do any of these happen to you?
Field.ElementLabel: You are treated with less courtesy than other people are.

ElementEnum.RawValue:
SDOH_24, Almost everyday 
 SDOH_25, At least once a week 
 SDOH_26, A few times a month 
 SDOH_27, A few times a year 
 SDOH_28, Less than once a year 
 SDOH_20, Never

 SDOH_25, At least once a week 
 SDOH_26, A few times a month 
 SDOH_27, A few times a year 
 SDOH_28, Less than once a year 
 SDOH_20, Never

Field.ElementPreceedingHeader:
The next set of questions asks about food and housing.
Lower food and housing security may increase the risk of negative health outcomes. Sharing your experiences about you or your family on this topic may help researchers learn how food and housing security influence health and well-being.
Field.ElementLabel: Within the past 12 months, we worried whether our food would run out before we got money to buy more.

ElementEnum.RawValue: SDOH_41, Often true \n SDOH_42, Sometimes true \n SDOH_43, Never true

Field.ElementLabel: Within the past 12 months, the food we bought just didn't last and we didn't have money to get more.

ElementEnum.RawValue: SDOH_41, Often true \n SDOH_42, Sometimes true \n SDOH_43, Never true

Field.ElementLabel:
In the last 12 months, how many times have you or your family moved from one home to another?
Number of moves in past 12 months:
Think about the place you live. Do you have problems with any of the following? Select all that apply.

ElementEnum.RawValue:
SDOH_44, Bug infestation 
 SDOH_45, Mold 
 SDOH_46, Lead paint or pipes 
 SDOH_47, Inadequate heat 
 SDOH_48, Oven or stove not working 
 SDOH_49, No or not working smoke detector 
 SDOH_50, Water leaks 
 SDOH_51, None of the above

StructuredValue.Value: No or not working smoke detector

Field.ElementPreceedingHeader:
The amount of stress you feel can lead to negative health outcomes. Sharing your experiences may help researchers identify common triggers that induce stress in individuals and ways to provide support for individuals and communities.
The next questions ask you about your feelings and thoughts during the last month. Please choose how often you felt or thought a certain way.
Field.ElementLabel: In the last month, how often have you been upset because of something that happened unexpectedly?

ElementEnum.RawValue:
SDOH_20, Never 
 SDOH_52, Almost Never 
 SDOH_22, Sometimes 
 SDOH_53, Fairly Often 
 SDOH_54, Very Often

 SDOH_54, Very Often

Field.ElementPreceedingHeader:
Elements of religion and spirituality can effect health outcomes. Sharing your beliefs and experiences may help researchers better understand the effects of religion and spirituality on health and well-being.
The next questions ask about your spiritual life. Some questions use the word "God." If it makes you more comfortable, you can replace that word with whatever you believe is spiritual, holy or divine when answering.
How often do you experience the following:
Field.ElementLabel: I feel God's (or a higher power's) presence

 SDOH_56, Every day 
 SDOH_57, Most days 
 SDOH_58, Some days 
 SDOH_59, Once in a while 
 SDOH_60, Never or almost never 
 SDOH_61, I do not believe in God (or a higher power)

StructuredValue.Value: I do not believe in God (or a higher power)

Field.ElementLabel: I find strength and comfort in my religion

Field.ElementPreceedingHeader:
Having a preferred language that is not English can be a barrier to health care access, use of health care services, and understanding health-related information. Sharing your English-speaking abilities with us can help researchers understand the relationship between speaking English and health outcomes.
The following question asks if you speak any languages other than English at home.
Field.ElementLabel: Do you speak a language other than English at home?

ElementEnum.RawValue: SDOH_67, Yes \n SDOH_68, No \n PMI_PreferNotToAnswer, Prefer not to answer

Field.ElementLabel:
Since you speak a language other than English at home, we are interested in your own thoughts about how well you think you speak English.
Would you say you speak English...

ElementEnum.RawValue:
SDOH_70, Very well 
 SDOH_71, Well 
 SDOH_72, Not well 
 SDOH_73, Not at all 
 PMI_PreferNotToAnswer, Prefer not to answer 
 PMI_DontKnow, Don't know

Field.ElementLabel:
If you or someone you care about needs help:
NIMH Getting Help page: https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/find-help/index.shtml
